ABSTRACT Investigating highly effective electrocatalysts for high-temperature proton exchange membrane fuel cells (HT-PEMFC) requires the resistance to phosphate acid (PA) poisoning at cathodic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). Recent advancements in catalysts have focused on alleviating phosphoric anion adsorption on Pt-based catalysts with modified electronic structure or catalytic interface and developing Fe-N-C based catalysts with immunity of PA poisoning. Fe-N-C-based catalysts have emerged as promising alternatives to Pt-based catalysts, offering significant potential to overcome the characteristic adsorption of phosphate anion on Pt. An overview of these developments provides insights into catalytic mechanisms and facilitates the design of more efficient catalysts. This review begins with an exploration of basic poisoning principles, followed by a critical summary of characterization techniques employed to identified the underlying mechanism of poisoning effect. Attention is then directed to endeavors aimed at enhancing the HT-PEMFC performance by well-designed catalysts. Finally, the opportunities and challenges in developing the anti-PA poisoning strategy and practical HT-PEMFC is discussed. Through these discussions, a comprehensive understanding of PA-poisoning bottlenecks and inspire future research directions is aim to provided. Graphical Abstract The mechanism and strategies to address the bottleneck issue in high-temperature polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (HT-PEMFCs), where phosphoric anions critically adsorb and poison the cathode catalysts, are explored for Pt- and Fe-based catalysts Keywords Fuel cell High-temperature Phosphate acid poisoning Activity degradation Electrocatalyst design 1 Introduction The development of proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFC) technology is supported by the major national energy strategy, which fueled by hydrogen is an efficient energy conversion device with the advantages of high energy density and efficiency, and low environmental pollution [1]. The most mature PEMFC technology is based on the electrolyte Nafion membrane. Due to the highly hydrated requirement of the membrane for proton conduction, the operating temperature is usually at ≈ 80 °C (namely as low-temperature PEMFC, LT-PEMFC). And additional humidification is required to maintain humidity of the Nafion electrolyte. Additionally, management of water flooding is troubling in LT-PEMFC, that liquid water floods the active site causes the performance losses in the cathode [2,3]. Besides, the impurity endurance is extremely limited in LT-PEMFC. Even minimal contamination of carbon monoxide, nitrous or sulfurated species etc. impurity in cathode gas (H2) or anode (O2) is harmful to the platinum materials [4,5], which is most effective and prevalent catalysts. The additional purification of hydrogen and infrastructures for high purity hydrogen transportation and distribution is high investment needed. Considering the above problems, increasing the operating temperature of PEMFC could break through these bottlenecks. Phosphoric acid fuel cell was among the initial viable fuel cells technologies to be explored for commercial applications and are now utilized for stationary power applications in several countries [6–15]. The-state-of-the-art phosphoric acid (PA, H3PO4) doped polybenzimidazole (PBI) electrolyte membrane was employed in high temperature PEMFC (HT-PEMFC), which enable the running temperature increase in the range of 120–240 °C [16]. HT-PEMFC offer a few advantages comparing to LT-PEMFCs as follow: (1) decreasing the adsorption of poisonous impurities on Pt electrocatalysts, significantly alleviating poisoning effect. Elevating the operating temperature ≥ 180 °C, the HT-PEMFC can tolerate a high level of CO up to 5%, without any significant performance decrease at cell voltage >0.57 V [17,18]. This merit will allow the chemical by-product hydrogen or reformed gas from alcohols, formic acid and other low-carbon chain hydrocarbon on board without purification directly fed to anode as fuel, thus cutting the significant funds in hydrogen purification, transportation and filling station infrastructure [19]. HT-PEMFC have operated using reformate hydrogen with up to 3% CO at 200 °C [20]. Meanwhile, raising operating temperature, the resistance to poisoning of cathode electrocatalysts is also greatly improved. When 0.01‰ SO2 is injected into the cathode side, the current of HT-PEMFC at 160 °C only decreases by about 8%, while that of LT-PEMFC at 80 °C decreases by 82% [21]. And the quality requirements for air/O2 on the cathode side are also relatively reduced. (2) simplifying the heat and water management systems because of evaporation of water above 100 °C [16,22]. The flooding issue can be eliminated, then the interface reaction at electrode is ensured by higher mass transfer. On the other hand, HT-PEMFC do not depends a gas humidification system [23]. Besides, the cooling system is also omitted [24,25], on the contrary, superfluous heat can be utilized to assist other reaction causes [26]. Raising the temperature, the cell operation system is greatly optimized in HT-PEMFC. (3) stimulating the reaction kinetics with the aiding of the thermo-electric coupling at both the cathode and anode [27]. Generally, expectation of improved reaction rates at higher operating temperature comparing to HT-PEMFC is principally because of the higher collision frequency on the electrodes [6,28], which expand the application market in HT-PEMFC of low platinum and non-platinum group metal catalysts. HT-PEMFC has many advantages in various aspects, but it puts forward higher requirements for key catalytic materials. Like LT-PEMFC, the cathodic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is still more complicated and sluggish due to the inherent thermodynamic limitations than the anodic hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR) in HT-PEMFC, and ORR catalyst is also the crux of HT-PEMFC research. However, the anticipation of deserved ORR kinetics improvement at the elevated temperature in HT-PENFC has indeed undermined by the phosphoric acid poisoning effect [6]. As an indispensable proton carrier in PA-PBI membrane-based HT-PEMFC, PA molecule has a strongly specific adsorption capacity on the surface of Pt catalyst [29–31], which is used almost exclusively on the cathode of PA-PBI based HT-PEMFC. Thus, the poisoning prevents the oxygen adsorption and oxidation catalytic process in Pt surface. Studies have shown that the ORR half-wave potential (E 1/2) of Pt-based electrocatalyst is reduced by 38–93 mV compared with the absence of phosphoric acid [32] due to the competitive adsorption of PA, and the current have been also significantly decreased. The in-situ studies reveals the tight bonding of PA on platinum sites even at elevated temperatures [33], greatly decreasing the efficiency of Pt-based catalysts and resulting in cell performance limitations. Furthermore, the passive influence on the Pt-based electrocatalyst in the membrane electrode assembly is echoed by the fact that the relatively high Pt loading is applied around 1.0 mgPt cm–2, which comes along with prohibitive material costs in comparison to lower Pt loadings of approx. 0.1–0.4 mgPt cm–2 for LT-PEMFCs [34,35]. The tight adsorption of H3PO4 on the Pt active sites is one of the dominating origins for the higher cost and lower efficacy of the PA/PBI based HT-PEMFC contrasting with that of Nafion membrane based LT-PEMFCs [36], and make the former a relatively less popular and practically mature fuel cell technology. These drawbacks stimulate the design and application of Pt-based catalysts directed at HT-PEMFC technology, which is principally related to the endurance to phosphoric acid poisoning. Fe-N-C catalysts, which have received extensive attention in the study of LT-PEMFC [37], its activity in phosphoric acid electrolyte is less affected by poisoning effect. Compared to LT-PEMFC, Fe-N-C in HT-PEMFC have obvious advantages: (1) the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide at high temperature can decline the damage of Fenton effect on the membrane and catalytic layer. (2) H2O is in the gaseous state when the temperature over 100 °C, which avoid the water flooding in Fe-N-C micropores, thus ensure mass transfer in the electrode. (3) the performance of Fe-N-C is expected to further increase with the elevated operating temperature. With these remissions, the Fe-N-C catalysts has a good application prospect in HT-PEMFC. Compared with LT-PEMFC, the advancement of cathodic catalysts in HT-PEMFC is still in its infancy. The relevant review about membrane [38], characterization techniques [39,40], phosphate distribution and regulation [41], and comprehensive review [26,42,43] include almost all aspects about system assembly and stability issue et al., are thoroughly described in previous literatures. The stability issues faced by catalysts in HT-PEMFC such as dissolution of Pt and its alloy, agglomeration of metal nanoparticles, and corrosion of carbon support also have been summarized [35,44–48]. The PA poisoning and solution to catalysts materials are only discussed in subsections of larger reviews. Despite the poisoning of PA causes the main performance limitations, comprehensive assessment for which is very limited. In this review, we mainly present in-depth research on vital cathodic catalysts which usually suffer more serious effect from phosphoric acid poisoning. As shown in Scheme 1 , we firstly discuss the basic principles and characterization techniques of phosphate acid adsorption issue of Pt-based catalysts and Fe-N-C. Second, we systematically summarize the strategies for resisting PA poisoning and the recent successes in application of the anti-poisoning Pt-based catalysts and Fe-N-C catalysts. Finally, a brief outlook regarding the directions our endeavor about HT-PEMFC should be directed toward is suggested. We hope that this review will offer the researchers with a deeper understanding of phosphoric acid poisoning on cathodic catalysts, and further inspire the reader with more progressive investigations to expedite development. 2 Principles of phosphate poisoning 2.1 Pt-O adsorption H3PO4 molecules have a strong adsorption capacity on the surface of Pt catalyst, which is 2–3 times that of perchlorate, sulfate and chloride ions [49]. The fundamental theory of phosphate poisoning is that the Pt site was hindered where H2PO4 −-based species placeholder impacts the efficiently continuous reduction of O2 and O-based species on the active Pt sites [7,50]. The bonding configuration of phosphate and hydroxide with Pt atom is quite identical by forming Pt–O [51,52] (Fig. 1(A) ) Nørskov et al. [53] demonstrate the origin of the overpotential for ORR on Pt(111) is the strong adsorption strength of ORR intermediate (Pt–O) (Fig. 1(B)). Thus, weakening Pt–O binding strength is, therefore, possible a common direction for increasing the reaction rate and resisting phosphate poisoning [53–55]. Hence, universal electronic structure tailoring towards Pt-based catalysts will synchronously and linearly alter the adsorption strength of phosphate and hydroxide [56], although the competition between phosphate anion and oxygen adsorption still exists. The d-band theory contacts the binding energy of adsorbates with the d-band filling state of the transition metal [57,58]. As shown in Fig. 1(C), when oxygen-containing species coupled with the metal d states, the d band energy level splits into bonding orbitals and anti-bonding orbitals. The bonding strength is closely related to the filling of the antibonding orbital on account of their proximity to the Fermi level (ε f). The closer (far away) of the d-band center (ε d, represents the average energy of the d states) shift to the ε f would lead to an upshift (downshift) in antibonding states and reduced (raised) antibonding filling, which bring about enhanced (attenuated) binding strength of adsorbates. Hence, it is proposed that regulating the d-band electronic structure of Pt can weaken the binding strength of oxygen and phosphate, which result in enhanced oxygen reduction kinetics in HT-PEMFC [59]. 2.2 H, OH, and PO4 – adsorption competition Kaserer et al. [33] demonstrate the adsorption competition between H, OH, and PO4 – (represent the H x PO4 (3−x)−, which are cannot be differentiated in Δμ means) on a Pt surface during operation, which is related to phosphoric acid concentration, temperature, and electric potential. As shown in Fig. 2(A) , the NEG and POS represent negative and positive maximum amplitudes of the Δμ. The careful classification of the positive and negative amplitudes, using their energy position, the ratio between them, and the comparison of the experimental and theoretical results, allows us to distinguish the different adsorbates with varying cell potentials. The resulting plots of POS and NEG, which are directly related to the adsorbate coverages. As shown in Fig. 2(B), at cell voltage < 300 mV, only H adsorb on the Pt sites. In cell voltage range 300–800 mV, PO4 – species arises and restrains H and O(H) adsorption, the PO4 adsorption have two arrangements: the significant amount PO4 adsorbed on Pt surface are not in order but are mobile; the co-adsorption with H and O(H), the adsorbed PO4 was compelled to bind in specific order. At cell potentials above 800 mV, only O(H) is bonded on the Pt sites, adsorbed PO4 species is compelled to dissociate. The elevated temperature narrows down the phosphate coverage potential range and improve the anion mobility (Fig. 2(C)), but is still too low to clean up the poisoning PO4 on Pt surface. Still and all, because of engineering and degradation problem, higher working temperatures does not seem to be feasible. Therefore, the catalysts design is important as one viable solution to phosphoric acid placeholder. For the factor of increasing phosphoric acid concentration as shown in Fig. 2(D), more PO4 landing on the platinum surface. Besides, in the variation of the temperature and the voltage, the configuration of the adsorbed PO4 transform due to the steric hindrance of high O/O(H) coverage, the change in adsorption geometry has also been discovered by Iwasita et al. [10]. 2.3 H3PO3 adsorption Due to the low voltage and the existence of gaseous H2 at the anode, the reduction of phosphoric acid to phosphorous acid occurs, it travels through the membrane, and adsorbs and oxidizes to H3PO4 on the cathode, which is another vital contribution to the poisoning phenomenon [61]. Lin et al. [25] also observed an oxidation peak of H3PO3 at 0.7 V during cyclic voltammetry (CV) in an high temperature-rotating disk electrode setup (HT-RDE) (Fig. 3(A) ), which is a feature like alcohol electro-oxidation behavior. The origin of H3PO3 is confirmed by the smaller anodic/cathodic charge ratio in 0.06–0.4 V in 80 °C-pure H3PO4 as shown in Fig. 3(B), implies a supererogatory electrons donation from other reduction reaction of H3PO4 + 2H+ + 2e− → H3PO3 + H2O at low potentials, and the produced H3PO3 to be oxidized at around 0.7 V. The phosphite is more likely to be adsorbed on the platinum surface even more serious than that of phosphate [62,63]. Gomes et al. [64] surveyed the poisoning effect of both phosphoric acid to phosphorous acid, they demonstrate that H3PO3 bind Pt surface with P atom in an invertedly pyramidal configuration P(OH)3, which is different from H3PO4. The competition adsorption between H3PO4 and H3PO3 was existent (Fig. 3(C)), it is required the development of strategies to remit the H3PO3 poisoning by, for instant, designing the corresponding catalyst design and/or minimizing H3PO3 generation with optimized electrolyte composition. The fraction of Pt sites covered by H3PO4 species was reported to reach up to around one fifth [12,49]. And the HT-PEMFC Pt-based catalysts suffer complex H3PO4 adsorption, the adsorption configuration, strength, coverage and stability are closely related to temperature, potential and PA concentration. The more details of PA adsorption behavior were revealed the easier to develop catalysts with anti-poisoning capacity. 3 Characterization techniques for PA poisoning 3.1 Cyclic voltammetry CV is fundamental for observation of phosphoric acid poisoning. When adding phosphoric acid to perchloric acid electrolyte, new peaks emerge in the CV profile at 0.25–0.3 and 0.5–0.65 V as shown in Fig. 4(A) , which is assigned to the specific adsorption/desorption of H3–x PO4 (3–x)– anion [19,29,30,65–67]. Besides, the platinum oxidated and reduced peak minished and shifted towards high potential because the oxygen containing species was hampered by adsorbed phosphate anions on Pt surface (Fig. 4(A)). It is an indispensable characterization mean for surface characteristics and phosphate adsorption behaviors observation, and widely used in current research. For example, Lee et al. [29] employed the CV to analyze the effect of phosphoric acid poisoning on Pt/C, and PtCo alloy, and PtAu alloy. The CV profile was great influenced by PA-poisoning as concern as pronounced new peak and suppressed and positively shifted Pt oxidated and reduced peak with the increase in Co content. For the Aucore-Ptshell/C, in the contrast, the CV curve was rarely changed in PA solution, implying the ability of PA tolerance with Au core-Pt shell structure. The surface-sensitive electrochemical tool of CV is essential for the selection of catalysts. 3.2 N2O reduction Utilizing N2O as a molecules probe, the number of adsorbed phosphate anions, types of adsorption sites such as steps, terraces, crystal facet, and surface compositions can be identified [29]. In H3PO4 electrolyte, the N2O reduction rate reduced remarkably, since sites where phosphoric acid has been adsorbed cannot adsorb and reduce N2O. Lee et al. [29] carried out the N2O reduction experiment to investigate the PA adsorption nature on PtCo and PtAu alloy. The maxima of N2O reduction current density at 0.2 and 0.3 V was attributed to the reaction at step edges and terrace sites. They suggest that the Co component introduced steps on the Pt terraces. The diminution in the N2O reduction activity is more significant at 0.3 V than at 0.2 V (Fig. 4(B)), suggesting a preferential combining of PA on terrace sites rather than step edges. In the case of Au skin-Pt core catalysts, the N2O reduction charge reduce 33.2%, which is significantly smaller than that of Pt/C (43.2%) in 0.1 mol L–1 phosphate acid. These indicate that the N2O reduction technology is a helpful tool for catalysts such alloy and core-shell to figure out the inside information of phosphate anions blocking. 3.3 In situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and Δμ technique The XAS incorporating the spectral subtraction method Δμ applied to the XANES region was a powerful tool for studying the catalyst poisoning effect of PA on the Pt-based catalysts (Figs. 4(C) and (D)). The XANES are acquired around –20 to 50 eV relative to the Pt L3 edge at 11564 eV. By means of in situ Δμ XANES technique, even the analysis of little changes in the signatures is realizable. Take advantages of the Δμ approach, and comparing the data with theoretical calculations, it enables researchers follow the signature of H, O, H2PO4−, and H3PO3 adsorbed on the Pt skin [64]. The change of average coordination numbers of Pt-Pt, Pt-O, and Pt-P can be extracted from EXAFS fitting spectra at different potential and electrolyte. Combining the information acquired from Δμ technique and EXAFS, it is feasible to in situ identify the feature of the adsorbate on Pt with variational potentials. He et al. [54] employed the in situ Δμ-XANES to distinguish the adsorbate behavior of phosphate anions between Pt and PtNi catalysts. They observed a shift to lower energy, which is caused by an elongated bond length, and as is well-known the bond length increases as the bond strength reduce, so they deduce that the addition of Ni weakens the Pt–O. Using EXAFS analysis and CV in combination, Park et al. [68] determine the fraction of Pt/C electrocatalyst covered by PA (θ PA). Specifically, the coordination number of Pt–O bonding originating from PA anion adsorption fitted from the EXAFS spectra is proportional to θ PA. Kaserer et al. [33] carried out the in-operando Δμ-XANES to explain the adsorption behaviors among H+/OH–/PO4 3– in Section 2.2, and investigate the poisoning effect of PA on Pt towards cathodic oxygen reduction under HT-PEMFC realistic conditions with a PBI membrane rather than electrochemical half cells at room temperature. With in-operando Δμ-XANES technique, severe phosphate anion coverage on Pt surface is perceived at various potential, temperatures and PA concentrations. Comparing these results with that collected from room temperature and lower concentrations, there is difference that phosphoric anion is observed at all potentials while at room temperature, but not found in-operando XAS measurements at high temperatures. Based on this, Kaserer et al. [33] suggests that the phosphoric anion is mobile when increasing the temperature. The Δμ XANES is also effective to investigate the interaction of the phosphate anions with Fe-based catalysts [6]. Theoretical results gave a |Δμ| of ~0.2 when the phosphate anion interact with a Fe surface. However, when the Fe particles were protected by graphitic layers from phosphate poisoning, the Δμ amplitude (|Δμ|) was within the noise range (< 0.005 |Δμ|) because of the uniformity of the XANES spectra with the presence and absence of PA. 3.4 In situ electrochemical surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy The electrochemical surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy (EC-SERS) collected during CV scans (Fig. 5(A) ), giving in situ information about the oxidation state of the metal and the recognition of the adsorbed chemical species [69–71]. Lim et al. [72] conducted the EC-SERS to research the adsorption behavior of H3PO4 anion on Au electrode in different pH solution. In Fig. 5(B), the SER spectra show a broad peak at 580 cm–1 at 1.3 V in the positive sweep and disappear below 0.8 V in the negative sweep. This peak is assigned to Au-OH, which is consistent with the peak in CV scans in the approximately potential range (Fig. 5(C)). A comparison of the CVs in the pH 9 solution presents an additional peak at 0.8–1.0 V (Fig. 5(C)). In the corresponding SER spectra (Fig. 5(B)), the peak at 795, 930, and 1090 cm–1 at 0.7–1.2 V during the positive sweep and 0.8–0.6 V during the negative sweep were assigned to vibrational modes of the adsorbed phosphate ion species in bidentate geometry and monodentate geometry respectively. But in the pH 2.2 solution, only the Au-OH peak can be identified by the EC-SERS and CV. The EC-SERS, cooperating with CV, can be used as powerful evidence for identifying the adsorption of H3PO4 anion, and help screen catalyst such as PtAu catalysts in acidic condition. 3.5 In situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy IR spectroscopy can be employed as an instrument to explore electrochemical interfaces and to characterize chemical adsorption species on catalysts [10,13,73,74]. Habib et al. [13] are the first who used IR to determine the adsorption behaviors of H3PO4 molecule or anion on Pt surface at different electrode potential. Nart et al. [10] found a transform in geometric configuration of the adsorbed phosphoric anion by applying IR. At potentials above 0.9 V, more oxygen binding to the Pt sites, the C2V geometry of adsorbed phosphoric anion with two Pt–O bond is forced to the single coordinated CS symmetry, on account of the steric blocking effect (Figs. 5(D) and (E)). Neophytides et al. [74] set up an electrochemical cell for in situ FTIR, the test temperature of this in situ FTIR equipping in HT-PEMFC is range from room temperature to 150 °C. However, there are no experimental results on phosphoric acid poisoning on Pt surface. 4 Anti-poisoning strategy for Pt-based catalysts Since LT-PEMFC and HT-PEMFC use the catalysts with identical Pt elements, which generally synthesized as nanoparticles loaded on active carbon, the fundamental tactics for boosting reaction kinetics in LT-PEMFC are applicable to HT-PEMFC technologies. But the strategies focused on PA poisoning is necessary. In the last few decades, researchers have exploited multifarious strategies to resist phosphoric acid poisoning for HT-PEMFC cathodic ORR Pt-based catalysts, (1) regulating Pt crystal planes, (2) alloying transition metal with Pt, (3) modifying Pt with spectator molecules, (4) encapsulating carbon/oxide on Pt, and (5) distributing and migrating phosphoric acid from Pt. 4.1 Regulating Pt crystal planes The d electronic state is structurally sensitive to various crystal planes because the coordination atoms numbers is distant in each plane, which influences the bandwidth of the d-band [59]. He et al. [30] investigated the ORR kinetic in perchloric acid environment on various Pt single crystal electrodes in view of the negative effects of phosphate adsorption. The extent of activity decline was disclosed following the order of Pt(111) > Pt(110) ∼Pt(100) due to the extent of the poisoning effect. The further understanding of poisoning effect is that PA bind with 3 O atoms on Pt(111) in a 3-fold site, but with only 1 or 2 O atoms on Pt(100) and Pt(110) [50]. From these results, it proposed that changing the facets would increase the ORR activity due to suppressed adsorption of H3PO4 anions on Pt surface. 4.2 Alloying transition metal with Pt Alloy catalysts have been extensively developed in HT-PEMFC to resist phosphoric acid poisoning, such as binary alloys PtNi [51,54,75], PtCo [76], PtCu [19,67,77], PtAu [29,72], PtFe [78], PtSn [30] or ternary alloys, PtNiCu [79], PtFeCu [80], PtRhCu [81]. 4.2.1 Pt skin and sublayer alloy structure Pt skin and sublayer transition metal alloy structure can be prepared by certain synthesis methods through dissolution and leaching of transition metal M. The structure of electrocatalysts is one of the key factors to resist PA poisoning and enhance the activity and durability simultaneously. Park et al. [51] take advantage of the acidic condition to synthesize a catalyst with Pt surface structure by etching transition metals and the subsurface alloy core structure (Fig. 6(A) ). The effect of the Ptskin-Pt3M alloy core (M = Ni, Co, Fe) structure on the adsorption strength of PA was demonstrated by electrochemical analysis and first-principles calculations. It was revealed that the Ptskin/Pt3Ni/C showed the weakest adsorption of PA, followed by the order of Ptskin/Pt3Fe/C and Ptskin/Pt3Co/C, and pure Pt. Specifically, They use the difference in ΔE ad between the Pt(111) and Ptskin/Pt3M surfaces (δE ad) to represent adsorption strength of PA, as positive values of δE PA indicate weaker adsorption, the order of PA tolerance ability was demonstrated as Ptskin/Pt3Ni > Ptskin/Pt3Fe > Ptskin/Pt3Co >Pt (Fig. 6(B)). As mentioned above in Section 2.1, the closer of the ε d shift to the ε f and the higher density of states (DOS) would lead to enhanced binding strength of adsorbates, so the weaker adsorption on the Ptskin/Pt3M surfaces than on Pt(111) can be seen in Fig. 6(C). The suppressed PA poisoning is ascribed to weaker adsorption of H3PO4 on the Ptskin/Pt3M surface. Alloying Pt with transition metals can decrease the adsorption strength of phosphate by altering the d-band electronic structure of Pt, the effect of which is like on the oxygen containing intermediate species for enhancing ORR activity [75]. Sun et al. [81] designed a PtRhCu@Pt/C with a dense Pt shell and sublayer PtRhCu alloy by coating extra Pt atoms on the initial PtRhCu nanoparticles (Fig. 6(D)). The key to achieve H x PO4 (3–x)– tolerance is the optimization of the electronic structure of subsurface Cu on surface Pt. They screen Pt x Cu electrocatalysts based on theoretical calculation results by regarding ΔΔE ads as an evaluation criterion [19]. As shown in Fig. 6(E), in view of the identical Pt-O binding mode of H x PO4 (3–x)– and O2, there is a scaling relationship between H x PO4 (3–x)– and oxygen-containing species adsorption energy, therefore, the smaller adsorption energy difference between them (ΔΔE ads = ΔE PA – ΔE O2) is beneficial to both improve ORR intrinsic activity and reduce phosphoric acid toxicity. The structure-performance relationship of electrochemical test indicates the performance and tolerance to H x PO4 (3–x)– of Pt x Cu outclass that of TKK Pt/C. The tremendous enhancement in the performance and stability of the catalyst are derive from the enhanced PA resistance by incorporating Cu (Fig. 6(F)), and self-healing behavior from the core-shell synergy effect by inhibiting both Pt dissolution and Rh leaching. The assembled HT-PEMFC realized a peak power density of 529 mW cm−2 in H2-air condition and 977 mW cm−2 in H2-O2 condition, and a 300 h long-time durability (Figs. 6(G) and (H)). 4.2.2 Intermetallic alloy catalysts A alloyed Pt single crystals Pt3Sn(111) was prepared to investigate phosphate adsorption by evaporating Sn onto Pt(111) in a stainless steel ultra-high vacuum chamber, followed by thermal annealing (Fig. 7(A) ). The poisoning effects was alleviative on the PtSn(111) for ORR activity comparing to those depicted in Pt(111) (Figs. 7(B) and (C)). The reason is manifested as that the adsorption of PA on PtSn(111) is weaker than that of Pt(111) due to the reluctance to adsorb phosphoric acid of emerged surface steps and defects by Sn alloying [29,30]. The efficient and robust electrocatalysts in HT-PEMFC can be constructed by a novel and versatile approach to finely induce lattice strain in Pt surfaces for regulating the PA adsorption behavior. Li et al. [80] synthesized an ordered intermetallic Cu-PtFe/NC alloy catalyst by a thermally driven interfacial diffusion strategy. The polydopamine and silicon dioxide were employed to chelate Cu2+ and Fe3+ ions for diffused and alloyed with Pt and protect Pt particles from agglomeration to form Cu-PtFe/NC alloy. Doping Cu to the PtFe ordered intermetallic alloys can compress the arrangements of Pt atoms by the lattice mismatch (Fig. 7(D)). The d electronic structure of platinum was altered by compressive strain effect. Then the regulated electronic structure of Pt benefits for weakening the adsorption strength between phosphate and Pt sites, then Cu-PtFe/NC exhibit a high phosphate tolerance (Figs. 7(E) and (F)). The robust activity and stability of HT-PEMFC with Cu-PtFe/NC electrocatalysts were achieved for at least 100 h with the low Pt metal loading of 0.5 mg cm–2 (Figs. 7 (G)–(I)). Zhang et al. [67] prepared a rhombohedral L 11-PtCu intermetallic alloy catalysts through wet impregnation followed by hydrogen annealing to withstand PA poisoning (Fig. 8(A) ). The electron migration from Cu to Pt in O-PtCu/S-C effectively modified the catalyst electron structure, resulting in a negatively shift of the ε d of Pt (Fig. 8(B)) and thus decreasing the PA adsorption strength on the catalyst surface (Fig. 8(C)). As a result, the mitigated phosphate poisoning was revealed by both room temperature RDE and HT-RDE (Figs. 8(D) and (E)). Contemporaneously, the prepared PtCu alloy catalyst represents a practical cell peak power density of 800.5 mW cm–2 at elevated temperature (Fig. 8(F)). 4.2.3 Other PtM alloy catalysts PtAu alloy catalysts with different Au contents were prepared by the electrodeposition process [72]. As shown in Fig. 8(G), with Au contents below 31%, the alloy catalysts show higher ORR activity than pure Pt, but it is severely poisoned by phosphoric acid adsorption. With Au contents above 31%, the PtAu catalysts show comparable ORR activity with pure Pt, but it exhibits excellent PA tolerance with PA, which was even higher than those without PA (Figs. 8(G) and (H)). These interesting phenomena conceivably originated from some competing factors: (1) suppressed PA poisoning at high Au contents, (2) declined ORR activity at high Au contents, and (3) boosted effect of phosphate adsorption for ORR. As shown in Fig. 8(I), alloying of PtCo with mitigatory PA poisoning is achieved by Daletou et al. [76] through adjusting the reaction pH above 12. The detrimental effect of phosphate adsorption on PtCo catalysts was indeed suppressed in terms of the shift of d-band center making PA adsorption weaker. 4.3 Modifying Pt with spectator molecules Another effective method to prevent the strong phosphate anion adsorption is to modify the Pt skin by adsorbing spectator molecules such as cyanide [82], organic amines [83,84], and binaphthyl thiols [85]. More specifically, it is based on the modification of surfaces on which the sites necessary for adsorption of phosphoric anions have been blocked, while freeing sufficient Pt sites to react with the oxygen. Strmcnik et al. [82] demonstrate the ORR results on Pt(111) chemically covered by an irreversibly adsorbed cyanide (Pt(111)-CNad). As shown in the schematic Fig. 9(A) , O2 can only use a handful of sites through interstice in the phosphoric acid anions coverage layer. While, the number of sites for ORR is greatly increased because H x PO4 (3–x)– anions is selectively hindered outside by the adsorbed cyanide and the coverage of CNad/OHad was lower than that of phosphate anion for increased O2 accessing. As a result, the ORR activity on cyanide adsorbed Pt(111) can go from a 10-fold improvement in the phosphoric acid electrolyte (Fig. 9(B)). A small amount of oleylamine (OA)-covered Pt nanoparticles featured an enhanced ORR kinetics in PA electrolyte [84]. The surface coverage of OA was directly associated with a downshift of d-band center relative to Fermi level, resulting in weakening adsorption strength of phosphate anions (Fig. 9(C)). Structurally, the competitive adsorption between organic molecule and phosphate anion can decrease the poisoning of strong anion adsorption (Fig. 9(D)). L-cysteine molecules functionalized on a Pt surface forms a coulombic barrier to separate the phosphate anion from the Pt active sites [86] (Fig. 9(E)), then the activity showed a clear increase in 0.05 mol L–1 H3PO4. Pre‐adsorbate restrain the poisoning of phosphoric anions, but it also blocks out Pt sites to some degree. Thus, the coverage on the Pt surface is necessary to be optimized as a function of ORR activity [83]. In perchloric acid solution, the catalytic activity declines monotonically with incremental coverage of butylamine. Nevertheless, in phosphoric acid solution, the performance at first improves with increasing pre‐adsorbate coverage, and peaked at a 20% coverage (Fig. 9(F)). Then decreased activity occur with ever-increasing pre‐adsorbate coverage. 4.4 Encapsulating carbon/oxide on Pt An effective strategy that forms carbon encapsulation on Pt or PtFe nanoparticles was put forward to facilitate anti-poisoning property [78,87] (Fig. 10(A) ). Jung et al. [87]. also prepared Pt and Pt3Fe1 nanoparticles encapsulated in ultra-thin carbon shells as a molecular sieve to PA. They claim the pore structure selectively allows reactant oxygen reach to the Pt and leads to outstanding ORR activity and durability (Fig. 10(B)). Hu et al. [78]. proposed that the protective shell can not only effectively isolate the Pt sites from CO, SO x , and PO x poisoning, but also suppress agglomeration, coalescence and Oswald ripening of Pt nanoparticles in the reaction process [89]. As expected, the PtFe alloy catalyst exhibits excellent fuel cell performance at 160 °C (Figs. 10(C) and (D)). Long et al. [88] combined alloying and surface modification to synergistically improve the ORR catalytic activity and phosphate tolerance of Pt. An amorphous Mo oxide layer was constructed on active Pt3Co alloy surface to enhance the phosphoric resistance (Figs. 10(E) and (F)). 4.5 Distributing and migrating phosphoric acid from Pt The fast proton-coupled electron process in PA solution will improve the reaction kinetics rather than poisoning the catalysts. Hence, it is also important to promote the penetration and uniform distribution of PA in the catalysts surface as the phosphoric anion approximating to the Pt sites will offer requisite protons. Huang et al. [90] modified carbon supports with SiO2 and further anchoring Pt nanoparticles to take advantage of the ability of SiO2 binding acids by strong H-bonding [90] (Fig. 11(A) ). The phosphate ions tended to adsorb on the SiO2 of CNT@SiO2-Pt then set the Pt site free to relieve the poisoning effect. The uniform distribution of phosphoric acid in the catalytic layer acts as a rapid proton conduction network for the cathode reaction in HT-PEMFC. Therefore, an excellent performance under reformate conditions was present benefiting from the good electrochemical interface between the catalyst and proton carrier (Figs. 11(B)–(E)). Phosphoric acid distribution in the catalytic layer can also be improved by nitrogen-functionalized catalysts [36,91]. The nitrogen groups induce the PA and build a PA network throughout the catalyst layer. Yu et al. [52] first applied a PtP2/C electrocatalyst in HT-PEMFC cathode ORR, which show surprising catalytic activity and durability in phosphoric acid environment (Figs. 11(F) and (G), the HT-PEMFC performance of recently reported advanced electrocatalysts is listed in Table 1 ). The phosphorus component was oxidated to a phosphorus oxide film, which binds PA anions more tightly than Pt surfaces and act as a sacrificial phosphate reservoir, thus leaving clean Pt active sites. And the structural stability origins from that the PtP2 species hardly catalyze the oxidation of carbon carrier. 5 Anti-poisoning strategy of Fe-N-C catalysts Another significant way to remitting the poisoning by H3–x PO4 (3–x)– anions is to replace Pt by Fe metal element in HT-PEMFC cathode catalyst. Fe-N-C catalysts featuring an iron center coordinated with nitrogen have shown unique activity for the ORR. Since MN4-based macrocyclic compounds to resemble the respiratory hem center were revealed to present certain ORR activity in 1964s [92], for 60 years, the Fe-N-C have been comprehensively and thoroughly studied from all aspects including mechanisms, identification of active sites, characterization tools, synthesis method, stability issue, and assembling and testing MEA applied as cathodic catalysts in LT-PEMFCs [37]. Kaspar et al. [7] investigate the catalytic behavior of Fe-N-C and Pt-based catalysts toward anion adsorption using RDE in aqueous HClO4, H2SO4, H3PO4, and HCl electrolytes. They confirm that the ORR activity of Fe-N-C is almost unaffected by anion poisoning than Pt-based catalysts. Besides, they proposed that PA does not poison the Fe-based catalyst, in contrast, it could axially bind on the Fe center to form a five-chelated Fe-N4 moiety and act as an electronic structure modifier to boost the ORR catalytic activity, contrary to Pt-based catalysts [6,7,32,93]. However, it is clarified that this effect is not detected in low concentration phosphoric acid electrolyte mixed with perchloric acid. Hu et al. [94] found the ORR activity of the Fe-N-C catalyst is in the order of H3PO4 (8.6 mA mg−1) > H2SO4 (5.3 mA mg−1) > HClO4 (3.1 mA mg−1) > HCl (0.7 mA mg−1) at 0.8 V vs. RHE. The results imply great opportunities for Fe-N-C applied in HT-PEMFC based on PA/PBI membrane. However, the extensive research and application of Fe-based catalysts in HT-PEMFC began only six years ago [95]. Development of stable and electrocatalytically active Fe-N-C catalysts to settle the cathode Pt poisoning matter by H3PO4 anions is of great technological and scientific significance. In principle, the performance of a Fe-based catalysts is primarily determined by the intrinsic activity and site availability including high sites density, optimal hierarchical pore for mass transfer and so on. 5.1 Increasing site intrinsic activity Although it is extensively approved that Fe-N-C catalysts are immune to PA poisoning, the intrinsic cause remains unclear and debatable, due to the varying active site structure reported in the literature based on the diverse synthesis method. Liu et al. [97] elaborately designed a FeN4-O active site configuration. The axial O functional group modifies the electronic and geometric structure of FeN4 moiety, which effectively weakened the bond strength of H3PO4 and its anions on Fe active centers. As a result, the catalytic activity of oxygen reduction is consequently increased in line with the theoretical simulation results. This study reveals the intrinsic origin of the PA resistance of Fe-N-C catalysts at the atom level. The versatile configuration of Fe-N-C materials with single-Fe-atom coordinated with four N atoms provides a wealth of opportunities to tailor the electronic structures of active sites by adjusting the coordination environment to increase the ORR activity. In fact, the traditional FeN4 configuration may be not perfectly fit in the H3PO4 system. Sun et al. [96] provide a feasible P-doping method to improve the performance of Fe-N-C catalyst (Figs. 12(A)–(D) ). The P atom is joint with the N atoms in FeN4 moiety. The optimized Fe-NCP catalyst exhibits a E 1/2 of 0.75 V in 0.1 mol L–1 phosphoric acid electrolyte, which is 60 and 40 mV higher than that of Fe-NC without P doping and the state-of-the-art Pt/C catalysts (Fig. 12(E)). The fuel cell performance at 160 °C is 357 mW cm–2 of peak power density (Fig. 12(F)). The improvement of activity is ascribed to the increased charge density and PA poisoning resistance of Fe active sites induced by adjacent phosphorus atoms (Figs. 12(G) and (H)). A non-Pt catalysts comprise dual-sites FeN4 and CuN4 (FeCu/N-CNTs) electrocatalysts was developed [98], by mimicking Heme copper oxidases (Figs. 13(A)–(D) ). Electrochemical test, theoretical calculation, and XPS indicate the strong and preferential adsorption of the PA anions on the Cu sites rather than on the Fe sites (Figs. 13(E)–(H)). Contrary to the poisoning effect of PA on Pt-based catalysts, FeCu/N-CNTs exhibits increased activity due to that the phosphate anion bonded on Cu sites drags local protons for the near Fe active sites where ORR occurs. The HT-PEMFC using FeCu/N-CNTs as cathode ORR catalyst exhibits a PPD of 302 mW cm–2 at 230 °C, comparable to that of Pt/C catalysts (Fig. 13(I)). And more stable activity is achieved with FeCu/N-CNTs for a 100-h long-time durability test (Fig. 13(J)). Strickland et al. [6] proposed that a carbon encapsulated Fe particles shows immunity to PA poisoning. The physical protection of carbon shell prevents the Fe active sites from PA anions adsorption. Hu et al. [99] also report a Fe3C nanoparticles catalyst with superior ORR activity and stability due to the cover of thin carbon shell. The performance of LT-PEMFC and HT-PEMFC are both evaluated using the Fe3C nanoparticles catalyst as cathodic catalysts in an operating temperature range from 80 to 180 °C. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first research of Fe-based catalysts applied to catalyze cathodic ORR in HT-PEMFC. 5.2 Improving site availability Low site density and limited exposure of single atom active sites due to the low metal loading in bulk carbon support make the low ORR activity. In the case of PEMFCs, the catalysts layer thickness usually increased up to 100 μm to obtained enough active sites for ORR. The thick catalytic layer inevitably increases the mass-transfer resistance and greatly reduce the performance of fuel cell. Rohan et al. [95]. used an Fe-N-C electrocatalyst as the cathode catalyst in HT-PEMFC. They improved a polarization of 0.65 V at 0.2 A cm−2 from 0.43 V at 0.2 A cm−2 by increasing the back-pressure of the PEMFC (from 0 to 3 bar), thus suggested that the main limitation of the Fe-N-C in application in HT-PEMFC was oxygen transfer through the thick catalyst layer but not the intrinsic activity of the active sites. Bevilacqua et al. [100] also found that the mass transport loss in the non-Pt catalyst is severe by appealing EIS studies and DRT analysis. 5.2.1 Increasing active site density Improving the density of FeN4 active sites is the one of the strategies toward the practical application of Fe-based catalysts for HT-PEMFC. The Fe SACs loading is usually as low as 2 wt%, and further improvement is as one of the grand challenges in single atom catalyst preparation. Because of the high surface energy of metal atoms and the lack of stable ligands, isolated metal atoms migrate and aggregate to form metal nanoparticles/compounds when attempting to increase the metal loading. Effective strategies for developing high site density Fe SACs include (1) isolating metal atoms to preventing migration/aggregation such as space-confined strategy, (2) enhancing the anchoring effect of carbon supports such as coordination with functional group, and (3) creating more anchoring sites such as N doping and defects. The experience of single atom catalyst synthesis strategies in the study of LT-PEMFC can be directly applied. However, it is worth noting that the structural stability of single-atom catalysts faces greater challenges in the testing process of HT-PEMFC than that of LT-PEMFC. The synthesis strategies and the as-prepared catalysts with high sites density should be carefully screened for high temperature systems. Several successful cases are reported below. Cheng et al. [101] employed a one pot synthesis method for developing catalysts with a high Fe loading. The catalyst is rich in nitrogen anchoring sites for the Fe atoms. The iron single atom catalyst (FeSA-G) with a high Fe loading of ≈7.7 ± 1.3 wt% was prepared. As shown in Fig. 14(A) , the E 1/2 of FeSA-G is negligibly changed (decline ΔE = 8 mV) after the addition of H3PO4, but the Pt/C catalyst is very sensitive to PA (decline ΔE = 27 mV), which shows excellent PA-poisoning endurance of FeSA-G catalyst. The peak power density of HT-PEMFC at 160 °C with FeSA-G as cathode catalyst is lower than that with Pt/C catalyst (276 mW cm−2 vs. 373 mW cm−2, Fig. 14(B)). In surprise, as the operational temperature evevated to 230 °C, FeSA-G perform better than Pt/C (325 vs. 313 mW cm−2, Fig. 14(C)). Meanwhile, The FeSA-G shows a significantly higher durability than Pt/C catalyst due to high phosphate anion tolerance (Fig. 14(D)) [101], a significant advantage of Fe-based catalyst for high temperature PA/PBI membrane based PEMFCs. Cheng et al. [102] use a straightforward template free method to synthesize a Fe-based catalyst with high Fe single atom site density (FeSA, 3.5 wt%). The high density may be derived from the condensation of the dicyandiamide (N source) with hemin porcine (Fe precursor) to avoid the formation of metal particles. The ORR activities of the synthesized Fe-based catalysts are comparable to Pt/C in 0.1 mol L−1 HClO4 solutions. However, the PA diminishes the activity of Pt/C with a negative shift as high as 28 mV for E 1/2 due to the poor resistance to PA of Pt/C catalyst. In contrast, the ORR activity on FeSA/HP catalyst is independent of PA concentrations. As a result, the FeSA shows a half-wave potential of 0.80 V, which is superior to that of Pt/C with 27 mV in the presence of H3PO4. And the applicability of FeSA catalysts at catalytic layer of HT-PEMFC outputs a PPD of 266 mW cm−2 and excellent stability at 240 °C. They conclude the outstanding ORR activity to the high-density Fe single atom active sites and high phosphate resistance ability. At present, the Fe site density has reach up to 7.7 wt%. Four nitrogen atoms and at least ten carbon atoms are required to coordinate one iron atom (Fe-N4C10 or Fe-N4C12), so the loading of dispersive Fe single atom is limited and difficult to be further increased. 5.2.2 Constructing porous morphology The morphology and structure of the Fe-based catalysts as function of metal precursors and loading were investigated by Zelenay et al. [32], and the resulted structure-ORR activity relationship is also revealed. The synthesized PANI-Fe-C shows high tolerance to high concentrations H3−x PO4 (3−x)− ions in 5.0 mol L−1 H3PO4, as a result, the ORR activity of PANI-Fe-C is higher than that of Pt-base catalyst. The optimized Fe loading of 30 wt% in PANI-Fe-C was evaluated to have the best performance correlating to the porous structure with the largest electrochemical reactive surface among other PANI-Fe-C catalysts with different metal loading. Different-sized silica nanoparticles were used by Kim et al. [103] to obtain custom-made pore diameters in a Fe-N-C catalyst. A hierarchical poly-mesoporous Fe-N-C electrocatalyst has been synthesized and applied to efficiently boost the ORR kinetics in PA electrolyte. Furthermore, HT-PEMFC using the Fe-N-C as cathodic ORR catalyst exhibited a high performance. It is considered that the optimal porosity in Fe/N/C catalyst present a large electrocatalytic active surface, and increase the mass transfer of proton and reactant. Fatemeh et al. [104] synthesized a hierarchical micro/mesoporous Fe-N-C catalysts (Fig. 15(A) ). The immunity to H3PO4 anion adsorption of the Fe-N-C catalysts has been confirmed by RDE technique (Figs. 15(B) and (C)). The high performance was also obtained from fabricated HT-PEMFC, which is related to the highly porous nature and anti-poisoning to PA (Fig. 15(D), the HT-PEMFC performance of recently reported advanced electrocatalysts is listed in Table 2 ). 6 Conclusions and perspectives 6.1 Summary Catalyst is the core material of fuel cell and its development is a necessary step for HT-PEMFC to be large-scale applicated and commercialized. Platinum-based and iron-based catalysts are the two most studied and promising candidates. Pt-based catalysts, who suffer the most severely detrimental effects of phosphoric acid poisoning, and perform not as good as that in nafion-membrane based LT-PEMFC, which does not meet our initial expectations for HT-PEMFC. Nevertheless, as the case with LT-PEMFC decades ago, all these problems will be progressively overcome, not to mention the fact that we already have experience in LT-PEMFC and more advanced ideas, technologies and characterization instruments than ever before. Targeted strategies have been developed in quantity nowadays, and the activity have achieved about 0.8 W cm−2 at 160 °C with a Pt loading of 0.5 mg cm−2. And the stability studies were also conducted over 100 hours. It is believed that deeply understand catalytic mechanism of phosphate anion adsorption on catalysts during practically running fuel cell environment, and elaborating catalysts synthesis technology based on anti-poisoning concept will most likely promote commercialization process of HT-PEMFC with Pt electrocatalysts. Fe-based catalyst, especially Fe-N-C with FeN4 sites, which is not affected in the phosphoric acid environment, but its activity also does not reach the level in LT-PEMFC despite the effort on improving sites density and intrinsic activity. It is worth pondering, and shows that the studies of Fe-based catalysts are not enough. But there is no need to be discouraged, after all, the research of non-precious metal catalysts is on the infant stage. Therefore, by reviewing the ongoing progress in platinum-based and iron-based materials, some insights can be extracted with a view to realizing their practical application in the more demanding PEMFCs as shown in Fig. 16 . 6.2 Perspectives (1) The adsorption characteristics of phosphate anion should investigate under conditions as close to actual operation as possible. The performance effect of the redistribution and migration of phosphate anion throughout the membrane to the catalytic layer on catalysts and evolution of catalytic sites during operation is not completely revealed by current characterization techniques. This is mainly due to the lack of operando characterization means, and the existing characterization techniques cannot simulate the actual environment well of HT-PEMFC. Besides, a large percentage studies only conducted on electrochemical experiments at room temperature than in assembled fuel cell. The electrochemical testing helps us understand fundamental aspects of the adsorption features of phosphate species on catalysts surface, but more profound understanding should be obtained in realistic conditions in HT-PEMFC under elevated temperature and higher phosphoric acid concentration. (2) Attention should be paid to the influence of of H3PO3. It is adsorbed on the surface of Pt via the Pt–P bond, so strategies to weaken the Pt–O bond are limited in their effectiveness for alleviating phosphoric acid poisoning. In fact, many species come from phosphoric acid dissociation and reduction under complex cell conditions such as H x PO4 (3–x)–, H x PO3 (3–x)– and some we don't know, which more or less influence the performance of catalysts in a variety of ways. It also emphasizes the significance of operando characterization. (3) Fe-N-C catalyst application should be aimed at the conditions in HT-PEMFC such catalyst design, catalytic layer preparation and catalytic theory, just like previously studied on Pt-based catalysts. Just mechanically transforming and applying Fe-N-C designed in LT-PEMFC to the HT-PEMFC system can only play a preliminary exploration, but cannot achieve high power output. The immunity to PA poisoning and activity contribution in operando of Fe-N-C needs to be confirmed in practical high temperature fuel cell, especially taking the working condition into account that the higher viscosity and lower oxygen solubility at high temperature and concentrated PA dopant. For example, the formation and stability of the optimized and commonly used HO-FeN4 structure in the conditions of high temperature and lack of water needs to be investigated. (4) Proton conductors other than phosphoric acid may be developed and studied with low poisoning to the catalyst and little harm to the activity and stability of the HT-PEMFC. Even the development of other membranes with better properties than PBI membrane and avoiding the use of phosphoric acid should be synchronized. (5) To highlight the advantage of HT-PEMFC, reforming hydrogen as fuel is strongly encouraged. The increase in kinetic rate is compromised by phosphoric acid poisoning, on which much efforts are unremittingly making, and the water management systems have also been greatly simplified. All in all, attention should be paid to the use of reforming gas in view of the resistant of impurity gas and the cost. If HT-PEMFC could exhibit good catalytic activity under reformed gas or air conditions, the investment will be greatly reduced. Many grand plans including equipping external or inner alcohol reforming systems will be further realized. The application of HT-PEMFC requires a multi-pronged approach. Li Tao received his Master degree in 2016 and his Ph.D. degree in 2019 from Hunan University under the supervision of Prof. Shuangyin Wang. He is currently an associate professor of the College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hunan University. His research interests are in thermoelectric coupling catalysis, defect chemistry and fuel cell. Xian-Zhu Fu is currently a professor in the college of Materials Science and Engineering, Shenzhen University. He received his Ph.D. degree in Chemistry from Xiamen University in 2007. Then he joined the Department of Materials and Chemical Engineering at University of Alberta in Canada as a post-doctoral research ﬂow and Lawrence Berkeley National Lab as a visiting scholar. From 2012–2017, he worked at the Shenzhen Institutes of Advanced Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences. His research interests focus on electrochemistry/electrocatalysts for energy materials and devices, electronic materials and process. Shuangyin Wang received his bachelor's degree in 2006 from Zhejiang University and his Ph.D. in 2010 from Nanyang Technological University, Singapore. He is currently a Professor of the Key Laboratory for Graphene Materials and Devices and College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hunan University. His research interests are defect chemistry of electrocatalysts, HT-PEMFCs, and electrosynthesis.

coredata.dc:description: ABSTRACT Investigating highly effective electrocatalysts for high-temperature proton exchange membrane fuel cells (HT-PEMFC) requires the resistance to phosphate acid (PA) poisoning at cathodic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). Recent advancements in catalysts have focused on alleviating phosphoric anion adsorption on Pt-based catalysts with modified electronic structure or catalytic interface and developing Fe-N-C based catalysts with immunity of PA poisoning. Fe-N-C-based catalysts have emerged as promising alternatives to Pt-based catalysts, offering significant potential to overcome the characteristic adsorption of phosphate anion on Pt. An overview of these developments provides insights into catalytic mechanisms and facilitates the design of more efficient catalysts. This review begins with an exploration of basic poisoning principles, followed by a critical summary of characterization techniques employed to identified the underlying mechanism of poisoning effect. Attention is then directed to endeavors aimed at enhancing the HT-PEMFC performance by well-designed catalysts. Finally, the opportunities and challenges in developing the anti-PA poisoning strategy and practical HT-PEMFC is discussed. Through these discussions, a comprehensive understanding of PA-poisoning bottlenecks and inspire future research directions is aim to provided.
